title: Data Sources
text:
The data for this project comes from the SCORE Sports Data Repository, specifically their Olympic Swimming History dataset available at https://data.scorenetwork.org/swimming/olympic_swimming_history.html. This dataset contains comprehensive results from Olympic swimming competitions from 1912 to 2020, including 4,359 individual race results.
The original data source is olympics.com, and the dataset was compiled and made available by datasciencedonut on Kaggle. The data includes all athletes who competed in Olympic swimming events, not just medal winners, which makes it ideal for understanding the full spectrum of Olympic-level performance.
Data cleaning involved converting time formats from minutes:seconds.decimal to total seconds for analysis, removing DNS (Did Not Start) and DQ (Disqualified) entries, and filtering out obvious data entry errors or outliers. No observations were removed based on performance criteria - the goal was to include all legitimate competitive times to show the complete picture of Olympic swimming performance.
The dataset includes the following variables:

Location: Hosting city of the Olympics
Year: Year of the Olympics (1912-2020)
Distance: Distance in meters (relays show number of swimmers × distance per swimmer)
Stroke: Type of swimming stroke (Freestyle, Backstroke, Breaststroke, Butterfly, Individual Medley)
Relay: Binary indicator (0 for individual events, 1 for relay events)
Gender: Men or Women
Team: Three-letter country code
Athlete: Name of the athlete
Results: Time in minutes:seconds.decimal format
Rank: Medal placement (1=Gold, 2=Silver, 3=Bronze, 4=No Medal, 0=DNS/DQ)

title: Olympic Swimming Times: A Century of Competition
text:
This project analyzes Olympic swimming performance data spanning over a century (1912-2020), examining how swimming times have evolved across different events and between men and women. Rather than focusing solely on winning times, this analysis includes all athlete performances to provide a comprehensive view of competitive swimming standards at the Olympic level.
The centerpiece of this analysis is an interactive ridgeline plot that allows users to explore the distribution of swimming times for each event, revealing patterns in performance consistency, the competitiveness of different events, and the evolution of swimming speeds over time.















Performance Consistency: Some events show tight clustering of times, indicating highly competitive fields
Event Difficulty: Longer distance events naturally show wider time distributions
Gender Comparisons: Clear patterns emerge when comparing men’s and women’s performance distributions
Olympic Standard: The data reveals what it takes to compete at the highest level of swimming

Navigate to the About page to learn more about this project, or visit Sources for information about the data.

title: Olympic Swimming Times: A Century of Competition
text:
Summary
This visualization shows every Olympic swimmer from 1912-2020 racing simultaneously through time. Each dot represents a swimmer, positioned in lanes by stroke type, with faster swimmers positioned further right.
How to use: - Play/Pause: Use the controls to start/stop the animation - Scrub through time: Drag the year slider to jump to any Olympics - Hover for details: Mouse over any swimmer to see their information - Explore patterns: Watch how performance clusters change over decades
The animation reveals the evolution of Olympic swimming - from sparse fields in early Olympics to dense competition in modern games, showing the dramatic improvement in performance over time.

title: Olympic Swimming Performance Evolution
text:
Key Insights
This ridgeline visualization reveals several important patterns in Olympic swimming:
Historical Timeline: - Men’s events began in 1912, while women’s participation started later - The visualization clearly shows when each women’s event was introduced - Performance trends span over 100 years of Olympic competition
Performance Evolution: - Blue trend lines (men) and red trend lines (women) show clear improvement over time - Medal winners (larger dots) demonstrate the evolution of world-class performance - Different events show varying rates of improvement
Gender Participation: - Women’s events were added progressively throughout Olympic history - The ridgeline format makes it easy to compare when different events became available for women - Performance gaps and convergence patterns are visible between genders
Technical Insights: - The visualization uses a normalized y-axis positioning for each event - Interactive features allow detailed exploration of individual athlete performances - Medal winners are emphasized through larger point sizes for better storytelling

title: Olympic Swimming Evolution: Men vs Women’s Performance
text:
Gender Participation Timeline: - Men’s swimming began in the 1912 Olympics across all major events - Women’s swimming was introduced later, with significant gaps in early Olympic years - This visualization clearly shows the delayed inclusion of women in Olympic swimming
Performance Evolution: - Trend lines (solid for men, dashed for women) show clear performance improvements over time - Gold medal progressions reveal how world records have evolved differently for men and women - Performance gaps between genders have remained relatively consistent across most events
Technical Improvements: - All events show downward trends in winning times, indicating technological and training advances - Steeper improvements in certain decades reflect major innovations in technique and equipment - Event-specific patterns show how different strokes have evolved at different rates
The clean design focuses attention on the historical narrative while maintaining detailed information available through hover interactions.

title: Olympic Swimming Performance Evolution
text:
This visualization shows the evolution of Olympic swimming performance from 1912 to 2020, focusing on how athletes have pushed the boundaries of human speed in the water.

# Data preparation with your exact column names
swimming_clean <- swimming_data %>%
  # Convert Results (time) to seconds for analysis
  mutate(
    time_seconds = case_when(
      str_detect(Results, ":") ~ {
        time_parts <- str_split(Results, ":")
        map_dbl(time_parts, ~as.numeric(.x[1]) * 60 + as.numeric(.x[2]))
      },
      TRUE ~ as.numeric(Results)
    )
  ) %>%
  # Filter out any invalid times and focus on individual events (not relays)
  filter(!is.na(time_seconds), time_seconds > 0, `Relay?` == 0) %>%
  # Create clean event names
  mutate(
    event_clean = paste(`Distance (in meters)`, Stroke),
    distance_num = as.numeric(str_extract(`Distance (in meters)`, "\\d+"))
  ) %>%
  # Focus on major individual events for clarity
  filter(event_clean %in% c("100m Freestyle", "200m Freestyle", "50m Freestyle",
                            "100m Backstroke", "100m Breaststroke", "100m Butterfly")) %>%
  # Create era categories
  mutate(
    era = case_when(
      Year <= 1936 ~ "Early Era (1912-1936)",
      Year <= 1972 ~ "Modern Era (1948-1972)", 
      Year <= 2000 ~ "Tech Era (1976-2000)",
      TRUE ~ "Super Era (2004-2020)"
    ),
    # Create medal categories
    medal_status = case_when(
      Rank == 1 ~ "Gold Medal",
      Rank == 2 ~ "Silver Medal", 
      Rank == 3 ~ "Bronze Medal",
      Rank <= 8 ~ "Finalist",
      TRUE ~ "Participant"
    )
  ) %>%
  # Sample data to reduce overcrowding while keeping all medal winners
  group_by(event_clean, Gender, medal_status) %>%
  {
    bind_rows(
      filter(., medal_status %in% c("Gold Medal", "Silver Medal", "Bronze Medal")),
      filter(., !medal_status %in% c("Gold Medal", "Silver Medal", "Bronze Medal")) %>%
        slice_sample(prop = 0.3)
    )
  } %>%
  ungroup()

# Create the interactive scatterplot
p <- swimming_clean %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = time_seconds)) +
  
  # Add background trend surface
  geom_smooth(aes(group = interaction(event_clean, Gender)), 
              method = "loess", se = TRUE, alpha = 0.1, 
              color = "darkblue", size = 0.5) +
  
  # Add points with era coloring and medal sizing
  geom_point(aes(
    color = era,
    size = case_when(
      medal_status == "Gold Medal" ~ 4,
      medal_status == "Silver Medal" ~ 3,
      medal_status == "Bronze Medal" ~ 2.5,
      medal_status == "Finalist" ~ 2,
      TRUE ~ 1.5
    ),
    alpha = case_when(
      medal_status %in% c("Gold Medal", "Silver Medal", "Bronze Medal") ~ 0.9,
      medal_status == "Finalist" ~ 0.7,
      TRUE ~ 0.4
    ),
    text = paste(
      "Athlete:", Athlete,
      "<br>Country:", Team,
      "<br>Year:", Year,
      "<br>Event:", event_clean,
      "<br>Gender:", Gender,
      "<br>Time:", Results,
      "<br>Rank:", Rank,
      "<br>Location:", Location
    )
  )) +
  
  # Separate by event and gender
  facet_grid(event_clean ~ Gender, scales = "free_y", space = "free") +
  
  # Customize colors with era theme
  scale_color_viridis_d(name = "Olympic Era", option = "plasma") +
  scale_size_identity() +
  scale_alpha_identity() +
  
  # Clean theme
  theme_minimal(base_size = 11) +
  theme(
    strip.text = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "gray90", size = 0.5),
    legend.position = "bottom",
    legend.title = element_text(size = 11),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12, hjust = 0.5, color = "gray40")
  ) +
  
  # Labels
  labs(
    title = "Olympic Swimming: A Century of Performance Evolution",
    subtitle = "Swimming times evolution by event and gender (1912-2020)",
    x = "Olympic Year",
    y = "Swimming Time (seconds)",
    caption = "Larger dots = Medal winners | Hover for details | Trend lines show performance evolution"
  )

# Convert to interactive plot
interactive_plot <- ggplotly(p, tooltip = "text") %>%
  config(displayModeBar = FALSE) %>%
  layout(
    title = list(
      text = "Olympic Swimming: A Century of Performance Evolution",
      font = list(size = 18)
    ),
    annotations = list(
      text = "Swimming times evolution by event and gender (1912-2020)",
      showarrow = FALSE,
      x = 0.5, y = 1.02,
      xref = "paper", yref = "paper",
      font = list(size = 12, color = "gray40")
    )
  )

interactive_plot

# Clean and process the data
clean_data <- swimming_data %>%
  # Remove rows with missing essential data
  filter(!is.na(Year), 
         !is.na(Gender), 
         !is.na(Results),
         !is.na(`Distance (in meters)`),
         !is.na(Stroke)) %>%
  
  # Filter for individual events only (exclude relays)
  filter(`Relay?` == "No" | `Relay?` == 0) %>%
  
  # Create event name combining distance and stroke
  mutate(
    Event = paste(`Distance (in meters)`, "m", Stroke),
    
    # Convert Results to numeric (handle time format if needed)
    Time_seconds = case_when(
      str_detect(Results, ":") ~ {
        # Handle MM:SS.SS format
        parts <- str_split(Results, ":")
        map_dbl(parts, ~{
          if(length(.x) == 2) {
            as.numeric(.x[1]) * 60 + as.numeric(.x[2])
          } else {
            as.numeric(.x[1])
          }
        })
      },
      TRUE ~ as.numeric(Results)
    ),
    
    # Clean gender labels
    Gender_clean = case_when(
      Gender %in% c("M", "Male", "men") ~ "Men",
      Gender %in% c("W", "F", "Female", "women") ~ "Women",
      TRUE ~ Gender
    ),
    
    # Identify medal winners (ranks 1-3)
    Medal_winner = ifelse(Rank %in% c(1, 2, 3), "Medal", "No Medal"),
    
    # Clean team names
    Team_clean = str_trim(Team)
  ) %>%
  
  # Remove extreme outliers (times that are clearly errors)
  group_by(Event, Gender_clean) %>%
  filter(Time_seconds > quantile(Time_seconds, 0.01, na.rm = TRUE) &
         Time_seconds < quantile(Time_seconds, 0.99, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  
  # Remove rows with missing time data
  filter(!is.na(Time_seconds), Time_seconds > 0)

# Define key historical moments in swimming
historical_events <- data.frame(
  Year = c(1912, 1936, 1972, 1976, 1988, 2000, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2012),
  Event_name = c(
    "First Women's Swimming",
    "Nazi Olympics",
    "Mark Spitz Era",
    "East German Dominance",
    "Seoul Drug Scandals",
    "Streamlined Suits",
    "Beijing Tech Suits",
    "Tech Suit Ban",
    "New Suit Regulations",
    "Post-Tech Era"
  ),
  Description = c(
    "Women first compete in Olympic swimming",
    "Political tensions, limited participation",
    "Spitz wins 7 golds, technique revolution",
    "Systematic training programs emerge",
    "Drug testing becomes serious",
    "Streamlined swimsuits introduced",
    "High-tech suits create record explosion",
    "FINA bans tech suits",
    "Stricter suit regulations enforced",
    "Return to textile-only suits"
  )
)


# Create trend analysis focusing on record progression
trend_data <- clean_data %>%
  # Focus on gold medal times (rank 1) for cleaner trend lines
  filter(Rank == 1) %>%
  group_by(Event, Gender_clean) %>%
  arrange(Year) %>%
  mutate(
    # Calculate record improvements
    Previous_record = lag(Time_seconds),
    Improvement = Previous_record - Time_seconds,
    Improvement_pct = (Improvement / Previous_record) * 100,
    
    # Mark significant improvements (>2% improvement)
    Major_improvement = ifelse(Improvement_pct > 2, "Major", "Normal"),
    
    # Rolling average for smoother trend
    Rolling_avg = zoo::rollmean(Time_seconds, k = 3, fill = NA, align = "right")
  ) %>%
  ungroup()

# Create the main trend visualization
p_trend <- trend_data %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = Time_seconds, color = Gender_clean)) +
  
  # Add historical event markers
  geom_vline(data = historical_events, 
             aes(xintercept = Year), 
             color = "gray60", 
             linetype = "dashed", 
             alpha = 0.7) +
  
  # Add trend lines showing record progression
  geom_line(aes(group = interaction(Event, Gender_clean)), 
            size = 1.2, alpha = 0.8) +
  
  # Add points for records with hover info
  geom_point(aes(size = Major_improvement,
                 text = paste("Record Holder:", Athlete,
                             "<br>Country:", Team_clean,
                             "<br>Year:", Year,
                             "<br>Event:", Event,
                             "<br>Time:", round(Time_seconds, 2), "seconds",
                             "<br>Previous Record:", round(Previous_record, 2), "seconds",
                             "<br>Improvement:", round(Improvement, 2), "seconds",
                             "<br>% Improvement:", round(Improvement_pct, 2), "%",
                             "<br>Location:", Location)), 
             alpha = 0.8) +
  
  # Add text labels for major historical events
  geom_text(data = historical_events, 
            aes(x = Year, y = Inf, label = Event_name), 
            inherit.aes = FALSE,
            angle = 90, 
            vjust = 1.2, 
            hjust = 1, 
            size = 3, 
            color = "gray40") +
  
  # Facet by event
  facet_wrap(~Event, scales = "free_y", ncol = 3) +
  
  # Custom colors and sizes
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Men" = "#4A90E2", "Women" = "#E91E63")) +
  scale_size_manual(values = c("Major" = 4, "Normal" = 2)) +
  
  # Labels and theme
  labs(
    title = "Olympic Swimming World Records: Historical Trends & Breakthrough Moments",
    subtitle = "Gold medal times showing technological and social impacts on performance",
    x = "Olympic Year",
    y = "Time (seconds)",
    color = "Gender",
    size = "Record Type",
    caption = "Vertical lines mark major historical events in swimming"
  ) +
  
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
    strip.text = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold"),
    legend.position = "bottom",
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )

# Convert to interactive plotly
interactive_trend <- ggplotly(p_trend, tooltip = "text") %>%
  layout(
    width = 1400,
    height = 900,
    title = list(
      text = "Olympic Swimming World Records: Historical Trends & Breakthrough Moments",
      font = list(size = 18)
    )
  )

# Display the interactive plot
interactive_trend






# Create era-based analysis showing rate of improvement
era_data <- trend_data %>%
  mutate(
    Era = case_when(
      Year <= 1936 ~ "Early Era (1912-1936)",
      Year <= 1972 ~ "Mid Century (1948-1972)",
      Year <= 1988 ~ "Modern Training (1976-1988)",
      Year <= 2008 ~ "Technology Rise (1992-2008)",
      Year <= 2012 ~ "Tech Suit Era (2008-2012)",
      TRUE ~ "Post-Tech Era (2016+)"
    )
  ) %>%
  group_by(Era, Event, Gender_clean) %>%
  summarise(
    Avg_improvement = mean(Improvement_pct, na.rm = TRUE),
    Records_set = n(),
    Best_time = min(Time_seconds, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) %>%
  filter(!is.na(Avg_improvement))

# Create era comparison plot
p_era <- era_data %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Era, y = Avg_improvement, fill = Gender_clean)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge", alpha = 0.8) +
  
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Men" = "#4A90E2", "Women" = "#E91E63")) +
  
  facet_wrap(~Event, scales = "free_y", ncol = 3) +
  
  labs(
    title = "Rate of Swimming Record Improvement by Era",
    subtitle = "Average percentage improvement per record by historical period",
    x = "Historical Era",
    y = "Average Improvement (%)",
    fill = "Gender"
  ) +
  
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold"),
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )

# Convert to interactive
interactive_era <- ggplotly(p_era) %>%
  layout(height = 600)

title: Century of Getting Faster: Olympic Swimming 1912-2020
text:
Based on this analysis of Olympic swimming data:
Historical Trends: Swimming speeds have improved consistently across all distances, with the most dramatic improvements occurring after 1960. This coincides with advances in training methods, nutrition, and pool technology.
Gender Differences: While men’s speeds remain higher on average, women’s swimming has seen remarkable growth rates, particularly in longer distances. The gap has been narrowing over time.
Distance Specialization: Sprint events (≤100m) show the highest absolute speeds but relatively smaller improvement rates, while longer distances have seen more dramatic improvements as training and technique have evolved.
Modern Era: The period from 1980 onwards shows accelerated improvement, likely due to professional coaching, scientific training methods, and technological advances in equipment and facilities.

title: Olympic Swimming Performance Analysis
text:
Conclusion
This analysis reveals the dramatic story of Olympic swimming through a data lens, showing how external factors created visible “stock market-like” movements in performance:
Key Historical Impacts Visible in the Data:

Tech Suit Revolution (2008-2009): The most dramatic period in swimming history, with records falling by unprecedented margins
Post-Tech Adjustment (2012+): A visible “correction” as times slowed after tech suits were banned
Women’s Integration: Clear expansion of events and participation from 1912 onward
Training Revolution: Steady improvements through the 1970s-1990s as scientific training emerged

The “Stock Chart” Effect: - Sharp drops in times during tech suit era (like a stock surge) - Gradual improvements during stable periods (steady growth) - Sudden plateaus or reversals when regulations changed (market corrections) - Clear trend lines showing the impact of major innovations
This approach transforms swimming data into a compelling narrative about how technology, policy, and social change drive athletic performance - perfect for showing that sports data tells stories just like financial markets!

title: Century of Getting Faster: Olympic Swimming 1912-2020
text:
The story of Olympic swimming is fundamentally about getting faster. Each generation of swimmers has built upon the achievements of their predecessors, creating a clear upward trajectory in performance.
The chart reveals several fascinating patterns:

Steady improvement: Both men’s and women’s speeds have increased consistently over time
